frame.name: Commonality
frame.definition:
<def-root>This frame contains words that describe a set of individuals which possess some <fen>Commonality</fen>, generally a common attribute.
<ex><fex name="Entities">Their</fex> <t>common</t> <fex name="Commonality">enemy</fex> was Britain.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Entities
FE.definition:
<def-root>This FE denotes the people in possession of the Commonality. This FE is usually genetive, the object of a postnominal PP, or null instantiated (INI), and null instantiaton often implies the public at large, as in "the common good".
<ex><fex name="Entities">Their</fex> <t>common</t> <fex name="Commonality">enemy</fex> was Britain.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Commonality
FE.definition:
<def-root>This FE denotes an object or attribute which is jointly posessed by the <fen>Entities</fen>.
<ex><fex name="Entities">Their</fex> <t>shared</t> <fex name="Commonality">parents</fex> were their only similarity.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Entity_1
FE.definition:
<def-root>One of the possesors of the <fen>Commonality</fen>. Can be singular or plural.
<ex><fex name="Entity_1">He</fex> <t>shares</t> <fex name="Commonality">a home</fex> with <fex name="e2">us</fex>.</ex></def-root>

FE.name: Entity_2
FE.definition:
<def-root>One of the possesors of the <fen>Commonality</fen>. Can be singular or plural.
<ex><fex name="Entity_1">He</fex> <t>shares</t> <fex name="Commonality">a home</fex> with <fex name="e2">us</fex>.</ex></def-root>

lexUnit.name: mutual.a
lexUnit.definition: FN: being possessed by more than one individual.

lexUnit.name: shared.a
lexUnit.definition: FN: Used by multiple entities, for multiple purposes, or in multiple ways.

lexUnit.name: common.a
lexUnit.definition: FN: Jointly used or possessed by more than one individual.

lexUnit.name: in common.a
lexUnit.definition: FN: A group is said to have something "in common" when each member of the goupr possesses that thing.

lexUnit.name: collective.a
lexUnit.definition: FN: A Commonality is possessed by the Entities yet not necessarily possessed by each individual in the group. For example, "Americans' collective bargaining power" does not necessarily imply that each American has bargaining power apart from the group.

lexUnit.name: share.v
lexUnit.definition: FN: to have a feature in common
